summary: Fragments of the homilies First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: Christmas and First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: Assumption of St John from Ã†lfric's First Series of Catholic Homilies, found in the binding of a cartulary.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: (fol. 4*r) IOHANNES SE GODSPELLERE | CRISTES DYRLING ǷEARÐ | on ðissum dæge |

notes.head: Explicit
notes.body: (fol. 4*v) ˥ hi ealle anmodlice ræddon þæt ealle | his gesetnesse aidlode ƿæron

objectDesc.extent:
260 mm x 151 mm (dimensions of both, including repair parchment - size of leaves).
224 mm x 151 mm (dimensions of both, without repair parchment - size of leaves).
objectDesc.foliation: Part of the preliminary matter to the cartulary. The preliminary matter is foliated 1*-5* in pencil (Wilcox 2000, p. 66).
objectDesc.layoutDescription: The leaves are misfolded: fol. 5* should precede fol. 4*. The present writing grid has 23 lines, but Ker 1957 calculates that there were 26 lines (p. 308).

hands.name: Main text
hands.description: fols 4*-5*. Ker 1957 describes 'a round uncalligraphic hand' (p. 308).

characters.note: ascenders are lengthened in the last line on each page.

decoration: The rubric and initial letter 'I' are in red. Capitals are touched with red.

history.provenance: Used since at least the sixteenth century in the binding of Harley 2110. Ker 1957 notes that the name 'Iohannes Wynchelse' (John Wynchelsea, prior of Castle Acre, Norfolk, c. 1510) is scribbled on fol. 5*v. It was later in the possession of Sir Simonds D'Ewes, then Randle Holme. It was purchased by Francis Gastrell, Bishop of Chester for Robert Harley, earl of Oxford.
history.acquisition: Acquired by the British Museum along with other Harley manuscripts in 1753.

admin: Manuscript described by Hollie Morgan with the assistance of Sanne van der Schee, with reference to published scholarship (2010; 2013).
